column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=2. Materials and Methods
#Text=2.1 .
#Text=Established LCA Principles
#Text=The impact assessment method we propose is intended as a sub-method of the life cycle assessment method .
#Text=LCA has been an established method to analyse the potential attribution of environmental impacts of value chains to products for over 30 years .
#Text=Its principles and requirements are specified in ISO 14040 and ISO 14044 .

#Text=The goal of an LCA is to highlight hotspots of potential environmental impacts in production processes , to compare the potential impacts of alternative materials and to improve the environmental performance of products .
#Text=Potential impacts are assessed via a number of impact categories , e. g. , climate change , acidification and land use .
#Text=The following four steps are determined by the ISO .
#Text=In the first step , the system under investigation and the objectives of the LCA are defined including the system boundaries and the relevant impact categories .
#Text=In the second step , the product inventory is analysed , i. e. , all material and energy inputs and outputs for all processes in the value chain are compiled .
#Text=The third step is the impact assessment as such .
#Text=The system inputs and outputs are quantified for each impact category .
#Text=For example , for the impact category Global Warming , this means that the data is translated into an amount of CO2 equivalent .
#Text=The last step of an LCA is the presentation and interpretation of the results .
#Text=A detailed description of LCA and its features can be found in Hauschild et al. .
#Text=The method introduced in this article can be categorized as an impact assessment method for the integration of biodiversity into LCA .
#Text=In fact , it is an impact assessment method which aims to quantify potential environmental impacts of land use on biodiversity .
#Text=The development of impact assessment methods quantifying land use impacts started in the early 1990s with Heijungs et al. .
#Text=They were the first to describe the impact of land use as the product of area and time , but at that point without the consideration of soil qualities .

#Text=Later on , the UN Environment Life Cycle Initiative ( formerly known as UNEP-SETAC Life Cycle Initiative ) defined the impacts of land use as a function of quality ( Q ) , area ( A ) and time ( t ) .
#Text=In this framework , the quality can be any indicator on which land use of a specific area has an impact over a specific period .
#Text=For example , soil quality , water storage capacity or , as presented in this article , biodiversity .
#Text=Two types of land use can be differentiated — land transformation and land occupation .
#Text=As illustrated in
#Text=Figure 1
#Text=, land transformation is the change from a reference situation ( Qref ) to another quality status at one specific time ( t0 ) .
#Text=Occupation means the continuation of the ( typically lower ) quality status over a time period ( from t0 to tfin ) .
#Text=The change of the quality ( ΔQ ) can either be temporary if it is reversible , or permanent if it is ( partly or entirely ) irreversible .
#Text=This approach is the basis for all impact assessment methods quantifying impacts of land use , and thus also for the method presented here .
#Text=2.2 .
#Text=State of the Art in Biodiversity LCIA

#Text=One consensus in LCA research is that beside climate change , pollution , unsustainable use of resources and invasive species , the main threat to biodiversity is the loss of habitat driven by the use of land for anthropogenic purposes .

#Text=Thus , biodiversity , including genetic , species and ecosystem diversity as defined by the Convention on Biological Diversity , can be one aspect that represents quality ( Q ) within the framework presented ahead ( see
#Text=Figure 1
#Text=) .
#Text=Several life cycle impact assessment ( LCIA ) methods consider biodiversity as a so-called end point indicator .
#Text=Nevertheless , there is no consensus on which indicators to use to represent impacts of land use on biodiversity in LCIA .

#Text=In current research , two main directions can be distinguished : LCIA methods which link land use to species richness ( positing : Q = species richness ) , and LCIA methods which link ecological conditions to impacts on biodiversity ( positing : Q = function of ecological conditions ) .
#Text=For the former approach , species richness of e. g. , vascular plants is commonly used as an indicator , often amended with species richness of several animal taxa .
#Text=The latter approach is usually based on a set of quantifiable conditions , e. g. , deadwood availability in forest ecosystems .
#Text=Additionally , new developments also aim to assess the impacts on functional diversity ( e. g. , ) .
#Text=However , these are only applicable in very limited contexts to date .
#Text=The LCIA method presented in this article calculates the impact on biodiversity based on the conditions that in all likelihood define the biodiversity on the patch of land under investigation .
